Award.AwardTitle: Neural and Hormonal Mechanisms of Vocal Communication
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding how hormones influence the nervous system helps reveal how the brain controls social behaviors like vocalization (sound production). Investigations of the simpler nervous system of fishes demonstrate that hormones dramatically influence the activity levels of individual neurons and neuron-to-neuron interactions underlying vocal behavior. Among fishes, vocal mechanisms and behaviors have largely been studied in one group known as midshipman. These studies are guided by the recent discovery that naturally occurring daily variation in midshipman vocal behavior is determined by daily changes in the activity of vocal neurons. Other studies in midshipman show that steroid hormones such as androgens and neurochemicals such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the vertebrate nervous system, induce changes in vocal neuron activity that mimic daily changes in vocal behavior. Neurophysiological, molecular and behavioral methods will test the hypotheses that daily changes in vocal neuron activity and vocal behavior depend on the actions of androgens, GABA, and the hormone melatonin that profoundly influences daily behavioral rhythms in vertebrates. The principles identified will apply to other vertebrate groups because vocal, neural and hormonal mechanisms are evolutionarily conserved between fishes and other vertebrates, including birds and mammals. This research has and will continue to train undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students from diverse cultural backgrounds and geographic regions and make the results of the research easily accessible to the general public through publications, press interviews and presentations at professional societies, universities, marine biology laboratories and local community science centers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit.  A practical way to address questions of sound communication is to identify behavioral, neural and hormonal mechanisms in species such as the fish model system studied in this project for which vocal-acoustic communication plays a central role in social behavior. Fish vocalization is under the control of a network of nerve cells (neurons) in the brain. This network shares similarities in structure and function with brain networks for vocalization in the other major groups (lineages) of sound producing vertebrates - amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals, including primates. Mechanisms underlying vocalization that are shared among all of these lineages include the actions of hormones on brain physiology and behavior like those identified during this project period.  The most significant results include those showing that seasonal and/or daily changes in behavioral state – in this case, nocturnal sound production by males to attract females for reproduction - are coupled to (1) changes in plasma levels of steroid hormones, in this case androgens (testosterone); (2) gene transcript levels in brain and vocal-sonic muscle for steroid receptors (androgens and estrogens) and biosynthetic enzymes for steroid production; (3) an internally generated circadian rhythm influenced by both daily light cycles and melatonin, a well-established time keeping hormone in many species, including humans; (4)  melatonin-dependent changes in the excitability of neurons in the brain network underlying sound production; and (5) abundant expression of melatonin receptors, along with androgen and estrogen receptors (point 2 above), in brain regions known to control reproductive behavior (limbic system) and vocalization (vocal network described above) in fish, as well as amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. The discovery of melatonin influences on circadian rhythms in vocal behavior and brain physiology, and the identification of locations for melatonin action in the brain, has widespread implications for sleep-wake cycles of behavior and large-scale patterns of brain activity in fish as well as in amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals.

 

Broader Impact. During this project period, the Principal Investigator recruited and trained a diverse population of nine undergraduates and two graduate students in behavioral, neural, and molecular methods of scientific investigation, inclusive of the acquisition of critical thinking and problem solving skills that will be valuable to them in the pursuit of any profession they choose to follow in the future. The Principal Investigator and students presented their scientific findings in high visibility, peer-reviewed publications that included graduate students, undergraduates and postdoctoral associates as co-authors with the Principal Investigator – these individuals also presented their findings at local, national and international conferences and poster sessions. The Principal Investigator also worked with other faculty to establish summer programs for undergraduate research experiences that attract a diverse community of students, co-organized symposia on the Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR), co-chaired a Cornell University committee on RCR, and helped to develop resources for RCR training of both undergraduate and graduate students.  The Principal Investigator and other laboratory members participate with other students in outreach activities at the local Ithaca Sciencenter and by presenting posters at local festivals, and participating in a Cornell University outreach program for graduate students (GRASHOPR). The Principal Investigator hosts a public exhibit on sound producing fish at the University of California Bodega Marine Laboratory. The Principal Investigator also provides photographs for children’s books, textbooks and websites, and interviews reporting his lab’s studies, fro example, for the BBC, Museum of Vancouver, Current Cast, Discovery of Sound in the Sea (University Rhode Island), Voice of America, Science News and Scientific American.
